prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's dive into this situation. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong for wanting to tell his girlfriend she can't bring her friend to his apartment anymore.

First, I need to understand the context. The girlfriend moved in temporarily after a fight with her parents. The author made it clear it was temporary. Then, the girlfriend started bringing her friend over. The author has had several negative experiences with these visits. The friend and girlfriend become catty, there's been awkwardness, a rude comment from the friend, and the girlfriend being rude to the author. The author is now considering telling her to stop bringing the friend over and pushing her to reconcile with her parents.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to evaluate both sides. On one hand, the author is a guest in his own apartment. He has the right to set boundaries about who is allowed in his space. If the friend's presence is causing discomfort and the girlfriend's behavior changes negatively, it's reasonable for him to address it. The author has provided specific examples of how the friend and girlfriend's interactions are unpleasant and even disrespectful.

On the other hand, maybe the author should have addressed the issue earlier. He mentioned the girlfriend's behavior changes, but he only acted after several incidents. Also, the girlfriend's friend might not be the root cause but a symptom. The girlfriend's own behavior when the friend is around is a key point. The author might need to communicate his feelings to her first before setting such a strict rule.

However, the scenario does show a pattern of negative interactions. The author isn't just being overly sensitive; these are repeated incidents. The friend's comment about the man having an opinion was clearly disrespectful. The girlfriend's attitude and the friend's sour look suggest a hostile environment. The author's decision to set a boundary by not allowing the friend in his apartment is about his comfort and well-being. 

The user's initial thought is that the author is in the wrong, but based on the provided details, the author is acting within his rights to maintain his living space's atmosphere. He hasn't acted impulsively but after multiple negative experiences. Therefore, the correct answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
